target_text: After spending more than a year as a German POW during World War II, Robert Bresson made Robert Bresson's debut with La conversa di Belfort (1943) in 1943

From Journal d'un cure de campagne (1951) (aka "Diary of a Country Priest") onwards, Robert Bresson created a unique minimalist style in which all but the barest essentials are omitted from the film (often, crucial details are only given in the soundtrack), with the actors (Robert Bresson calls the actors "models") giving deliberately flat, expressionless performances

It's a demanding and difficult, intensely personal style, which means that Robert Bresson's films never achieved great popularity (it was rare for Robert Bresson to make more than one film every five years), but Robert Bresson has a fanatical following among critics, who rate Robert Bresson as one of the greatest artists in the history of the cinema
